WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
May 24, 1910
Dr. Juan Guiteras,
Director de Sanidad,
Havana, Cuba.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I am directed by the Surgeon General to acknowledge with thanks the
receipt of your letter with reference to the failure in his letter to the Honorable
Robert L. Owen, Senator, U.S.A., to do justice to Mr. John R. Taylor in the mat-
ter of credit due him for submitting to yellow fever experiments.

This office is pleased to receive any additional information with regard
to the volunteers in this great work. On account of the length of time taken
to receive a reply from Havana and Panama it was not possible to consult either
yourself or Colonel Gorgas as to details in the preparation of the letter refer-
red to, but the greatest pains was taken to consult every conceivable source of
original information.

The facts with regard to Mr. Taylor were taken from your report of the
Inoculation Station at Las Animas Hospital, published as appendix “N” to the
report of Major Gorgas, Chief Sanitary Officer, Department of Cuba, for the year
1901. In that report, page 390, appears the following motion of his case:-

“Case V (case 27 of the tables), chart VII Taylor, native
of England, age 33 years. Assistant in the Inoculation Station.
Resident on the Island four months. He had been previously bitten
on six occasions. (See Nos. 13, 14, 15, 20 and 29 of the tables).”

As in the other cases the nationality of the patient is given with the name
of the patient, it would seem that this office had the very excellent authority
of your own report for the statement that Mr. Taylor was an Englishman at the
time of these experiments.

Further information is requested as to the date and place of Mr. Taylor's
birth, the date of his coming to the United States and the date and place of
-2-
his naturalization in order that this information may be placed on file and
made use of when the opportunity occurs.

Will you also, if the information is obtainable, inform this office as
to the amount of the rewards paid to Mr. Taylor and the other persons in the
series of experimental cases reported by you.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, J.R. Kean. Lt. Colonel, Medical Corps, U.S. Army.
132330
The above signed by J.R. Kean.
